DOCTOR: When I was last here it was frozen at a moment in Time. Now it's just freezing cold. Things must have deteriorated quite badly if the rain has started.
DOCTOR: There's a figure over there. He may need our help if he's injured.
AMV: In a crash, for instance?
DOCTOR: Yes.
AMY: We should be looking for Pargrave, not chasing a complete stranger.
DOCTOR: Looks like a bipedal canine. Maybe he's got a scent of something. Come on, he can lead us to Pargrave and the others.
AMY: And to the Chaos Pool. We have come full circle, Amy.
ASTRA: [OC]: Unidentified space vessel, this is the Presidential spacecraft...
AMY: You shan’t have these segments. I sense them here in this satchel with me. So close.
VOICE: [OC]: But you will be brought before me, Tracer.
AMY: No!
VOICE: [OC]: You have no choice. The end of order approaches. And you are drawn inexorably to me here at the Chaos Pool.
FREEDOM FIGHTERS: Chaos Pool. (repeats)
VOICE: [OC]: The Disciples of Chaos are gathering from the furthest reaches of the universe. We shall face the final confrontation together.
FREEDOM FIGHTERS: (repeating) Together.
VOICE: [OC]: All things shall converge here, and then Chaos shall reign forever.

elements.text: [Part Three]
[OC]: The final members of my army are arriving. Astra.
(echoes) Astra?
[OC]: And Pargrave.
(echoes) Pargrave.
The Voice laughs.
(echoes) Pargrave, don't get...
Too far ahead of us.
Captain Pargrave! I can see the light from his torch. He's crossed the stream, not far ahead. How are you doing, Lydall?
I'm still soaked from the storm, and the water's making these rocks slippery. I - I'm taking it carefully because of my hip. Ah! Oh no! Oh, my stick. Oh!
It's dropped right through the crack.
Can you see it?
Shine your torch down here too. No. The stream must have carried it away.
Oh, I'll have to manage without it.
That satchel looks like a burden. I could carry that for you.
I wouldn't dream of asking you to be my porter, Madam President.
Well, do you want to rest for a while?
Oh no, I'll be fine, thank you. Surprisingly I'd rather not stop. I feel compelled to persevere.
Yes, strange. Me too. Do you think it's getting colder?
Warmer, if anything.
Come on. Pargrave? Wait for us.
Oh my.
What? That's astonishing. Where's the light coming from?
Impressive, isn't it? Looks like a huge mausoleum.
Are they tombs? There are scores of them.
Maybe hundreds. See? They reach all the way up the walls. I can hardly count the ones at the top. The carvings on the monuments. These are the creatures that attacked the Eschaton.
Teuthoidians?
Is that what the Doctor called them?
Never mind the Doctor. We must keep moving.
How do you know which way to go, Captain? Do you feel what I feel - like you're being drawn onwards?
It's through here.
It? What is?
Our path.
Our path? Come on, Professor, let's follow our path. Don't forget your satchel.
The satchel is disintegrating. The segments are decaying and destroying everything around them. Doctor? I'm going to die in here.
[OC]: I wouldn't dream of asking you to be my porter, Madam President.
Is that you? Can you hear me? Can you hear me?
[OC]: I'm beginning to think you might...
Be right about this satchel.
Please let me carry the satchel for you, Lydall. It must be getting heavy.
Not heavy, no. It feels warmer though. It's odd.
[OC]: Can you hear me? Can you hear me?
What's that? Is someone there?
It's this mausoleum, Professor. It gives me the creeps too.
I'm sure I heard a voice.
Perhaps ahead of us in the cave network? Pargrave? Is there someone with you? What's that?
(distant) We must press on.
I shan't be sorry to leave this place.
Howling.
Oh, I heard that.
It's an animal. It could just be sheltering from the storm.
Or tracking us through it. Come on.
Where's that dog thing gone? Oh, we've lost it.
Him. We've lost him. I don't think he needs a torch.
Howling.
Or perhaps not. Come on. There's no other way. He must have gone through that archway. We can still catch up and escape this rain. Better to be under cover.
AMY-ZARA: All right for you in that thing.
Oh! Hope it regains its shape. I'm rather fond of this hat.
AMY-ZARA: That dog thing got away. It wasn't ... He wasn't in any crash.
Unlike us.
An air hostess once told me that landings are just controlled crashes. Our canine friend probably relied on his auto-pilot too.
It's a matter of trust. Do you think Pargrave trusted his auto-pilot, Doctor? He didn't trust me. And now he...
As a matter of fact, I don't entirely trust you either. Where's the real Amy?
What do you mean?
Oh, come along. You've been a very poor impostor, Zara. Just look at you. In fact, I should have in my pocket... Yeah. Here it is.
What's that? A knife?
No, it's just a mirror. Look at yourself. Go on.
I've changed.
I know that feeling. I noticed your appearance was altering in the life raft, but I've known you weren't Amy for much longer than that.
And said nothing?

I've let you lead me on in the hope I'd find out what really happened to Amy. Your mutual existence is bound together as Tracers. Now that you're both becoming human, well, I'm beginning to worry more about the real Amy.
I thought I had you fooled.
You're too obvious, Zara. For example, maybe Pargrave was killed on landing...
Don't say that!
But Amy would be worried for his sake. You're only worried for yourself, because Pargrave abandoned you on the Eschaton.
Oh, that's not fair!
Where is she, Zara?
You said we'd find the sixth...
Zara...
You said that dog-headed monstrosity could sniff it out for us.
Where is Amy?
Oh, she's in the satchel!
What? That could kill her.
Pargrave is... Pargrave is very determined.
He says the Chaos Pool is close.
I think exhaustion and collapse are closer.
He seems to know the route, even though we've never been here before.
Like déja vu. Ow!
Oh, your hip?
The satchel. It gave me an electric shock. Ow!
Your hand. Pargrave, wait! The Professor is injured.
(distant) What's the problem?
Just leave it behind, Lydall.
[OC]: Who is that? Who's out there?
I'm not sure.
What use is a battered old satchel anyway? Oh, those are awful blisters, Lydall, and we abandoned the medikit in the wreck of the life raft.
What's the delay?
Just wait. How could the satchel burn you? What's in that thing?
I don't know. I can't open it. The buckle has bent. Look at the strap, it's disintegrated. And the
leather is splitting.
[OC]: No. Do not leave the satchel. Bring it to me.
No. Do not leave the satchel.
Bring it to...
Oh, make your mind up. Oh. Forgive my impertinence, Madam President.
Bring the satchel. Pargrave will lead the way.
What were you thinking?
I trapped Amy in the satchel, all right? Used the transforming power of the segments to disguise myself as her. Well done, you're so smart. Happy now?
Happy? I'm appalled. The pan-dimensional forces in that satchel could... Why, Zara?

Well, you trust her, don't you, Doctor? I was thinking you'd never help me find the sixth segment, but you'd lead Amy right to it. Thought I'd got it too, when you told me about Astra. Huh. Didn't see that, did you? Not so smart after all.
No. Well, I...
And now look at me. No use as a Tracer because I'm turning human. Can't locate the segments anyway, because they're hidden in the bag.
Well, we'll just have to hope that Lydall brought the bag with him, won't we? Assuming of course that their life raft wasn't crushed beneath the wreck of the Eschaton.
Zara cries.
Oh. Ev...
He can't be.
Here.
Is this a trick?
Er, no, no, it's called a hug.
But my eyes are making your shoulder wet.
It's already soaked from the storm.
What's happening to me?
They're tears, Zara. Have you never cried before?
Pargrave makes me... makes me...
Makes you feel this way.
Yes. Thank you. I, I'll be fine now.
Tell me about Pargrave.
I found him on Atrios. I was going to use him just like I was using you, Doctor. Like I used Zinc.
You left Zinc to die on Mars.
Did I?
Yes. No tears for him, Zara? What's so special about Pargrave?

Pargrave is the 6th son of his family's 6th generation. I knew he would lead me back to the Chaos Pool. It's in his very essence, like the pilots of all those space craft we saw back there in the scrap-yard.
They were drawn here too.
From across the universe.
Remarkable.

Pargrave was in pieces when I met him. I was with him only a few months. Such a terrible time for him. His partner Francine and their children, they aged and died so swiftly. I made sure I stayed close to him. I just didn't expect... how close I'd got.
You fell in love, for the first time in your short life. And Pargrave doesn't know?
The Chaos Pool is all he cares about. That's why he abandoned us on the Eschaton, Doctor. Abandoned me. Didn't need me any more.
Shh, shh! I don't think we have to worry about finding our canine friend. Quiet, Zara! He'll hear you.
[OC]: Help me, Zara! Things are falling apart. Help me!
The satchel is decaying, Doctor, just like the segments.
Where is it? What's happened to Amy?
We must recover the satchel. We must recover the Key to Time.
And Amy.
I suppose.
Quickly Zara, before that creature gets our scent. Too late.
Those doors are huge. Are you sure we could open them?
That one's slightly ajar. You can hear what's beyond them.
Let's take a look. What a crowd. Maybe a couple of hundred. That figure by the Pool. I imagine she's in charge. It that a mask? No, no, it's her face.
They're waiting.
Oh - and look at the waterfall. It drops straight into a big pool.
What's so important about that?
You can see a reflection on the surface, but there's no splashing when the waterfall hits it. It must be the Chaos Pool.
All a bit cloak and dagger don't you think?
I see what you mean about the cloak. It does nothing for her, does it?
No, I meant us. Skulking in this ante-chamber like this.
No, wait. We don't know what they are.
Join us, President Astra.
Astra!
What?
Pargrave told you. They're waiting, for us.
Door opens.
Astra.
Astra.
Come in.
Come in.
They know who we are.
+ VOICE: Of course they do.
Step out into the dark.
Come on, Pargrave.
No. Don't go in.
They're expecting us.
What's it doing?
Ah-ah.
Yeah right, now is the time for etiquette. What is he doing?
Waving.
What big teeth he has.
All the better for smiling at us, I hope. Hello, I'm the Doctor, and this is Zara. He's not threatening us, he's beckoning us.
What was all that howling before, then?
Calling out. He wanted company. Come on. He's going without us. This is novel, being taken for a walk by the dog.
The freedom fighters welcome you both.
Welcome.
The Chaos Pool. I thought I'd never see it.
Captain Pargrave. 6th son of your 6th generation. President Astra, 6th daughter of a 6th Royal House. But there is a third. He has the segments.
Come out, Professor.
What is this place?
The Chaos Pool. Is this not what you have sought for so long?
On the Eschaton the Doctor mentioned segments too. Are they in this satchel? It burns.
Who is this?
This is Professor Lydall.
No. Stay where you are!
Why are you afraid of me?
Silence! He doesn't fully understand. Pargrave?
Mistress.
Bring me that satchel.
You can't have it. Ah! Oh, it burns. Madam President, we must leave this dreadful place. The Chaos Pool is nothing like I imagined. This is wrong.
Give us the segments, Lydall.
Us? Oh Astra, not you as well.
Surrender it to me. There are a thousand freedom fighters here. You have nowhere to run.
Tell them to take it from me. No. Look at them cowering. Are they afraid of me, or whatever it is in this satchel? You shan't have it!
Should I bring him back, Mistress?
No. He will not pass through the Teuthoidian horde. And besides, my true master will arrive here soon.
We know nothing about this dog thing.
We know his bark is worse than his bite.
You're very trusting, Doctor.
You make that sound like a bad thing. Mind your step. This stream has made these stones somewhat treacherous. Our friend seems very sure-footed.
Outside in the storm, Doctor, you wanted to help him even then. I can't decide whether that was brave or foolhardy.
The line between them can be somewhat indistinct.
How did you know it would be safe?
I didn't. Nor that I would just abandon someone who might need my help.
And now?
Well, he's wagging his tail. It's supposed to be a good sign, isn't it? He's as harmless as a lamb.
Then why do I feel like the sheep? Is he helping us or herding us. Oh!
Are you all right, Zara? Here. Let me help you up.
Look what I’ve found.
Professor Lydall's walking-stick. Must have been washed downstream.
I hope he's all right. Come on, we need to find him.
That's more like it, Zara, don't abandon someone who might need our help.
He has the segments in my satchel.
Sounds like our friend has found something.
Oh, wow. Look at this. It's a graveyard. A huge graveyard.
A mausoleum.
Hundreds of tombs. Look how high up they go.
That's where the light's coming from. Natural illumination. Look at the carvings. Recognise this fellow?
Yeah. I'm an expert on giant stone slugs. What do you think?
Well, the dedication might give you a clue. See? Commander Hectocot.
Hmm, he's quieter than I remember.
Yes, finally at peace. This mausoleum is the last resting place of the Teuthoidians. How is that possible?
What, 'cos they were alive and well attacking the Eschaton less than an hour ago?
No, because this is the planet of Chaos, Zara. It has been held in stasis only minutes away from the end of the universe.
You said that the Teuthoidians were from the other end of Time.
Precisely.
Barking.
Is it safe?
Some of the stones are coming loose. Try to stay away from the walls.
That's not loose stones. The statues are splitting apart.
It's Commander Hectocot. Silent no longer.
I knew it was too good to be true.
Vermin. The pestilential infestation.
Look out!
Howling.
Stay back, Doctor. You can't save the dog thing.
That dog thing was helping us. We can't just abandon him. Let go of me, Zara.
It's too late for him. The other monuments are splitting open. There are too many of them!
That poor creature.
You couldn't save him.
I could have tried.
We have to go. Come on, down this tunnel.
Teuthoidian cohort, to me.
Lieutenant Maddenjot reporting for duty, sir.
Yes, all right, Maddenjot, gather...
(distant) The whole corps. Get them ready for pursuit.
How can they be here?
The planet of Chaos exists on a fold in Time that puts the beginning and the end of the universe side by side. The mausoleum must be a weak point. I couldn't save that poor creature.
Would you really have sacrificed yourself to save it? You amaze me, Doctor.
Your sister Amy said something very similar. Perhaps you're more alike than you care to admit.
Something's ahead of us. We're trapped.
No, wait! Professor Lydall.
He has the satchel.
I understand now, Zara. Here, take it.
Be careful, Zara. Look how it’s scorching his hands.
Oh, it burns!
Give me the satchel. And my bracelet too.
Oh, it burns so brightly!
Zara, no.
At last.
Something breaks, scream.
Amy.
Doctor. Doctor.
Zara opened the satchel and let you out again.
The segments. Where are the segments?
The satchel was disintegrating. The decaying segments were destroying it.
It's all right, Amy. Look there. All that's left of the satchel.
The segments must be here somewhere. Where are they?
Oh Doctor, I thought I was going to die in there.
Let's try to avoid dying anywhere. The Teuthoidians are right behind us.
What, those awful slug creatures? Where are we, Doctor?
I'll explain as we go. Lydall, what's down there? Lydall! You came from that direction. What's down there?
Where are the segments?
(distant) The vermin are in this tunnel.
The torch. Pass me the torch.
Come on, Amy. Zara, Professor Lydall, we can't wait any longer.
I have waited so long for you, haven't I?
Yes you have. And I have awoken. Now, where are the segments?
I can't sense them. The Doctor said I might be more human than Tracer.
Your powers have not abated.
But before. I couldn't detect the segments when they were in the s... The other satchel.
They're in your satchel?
The segments are decaying badly. I had to stop them destroying Zara's satchel and me with it. At first I struggled to find them in there until I realised I just had to let them find me.
You are brilliant.
Where are we going?
I'm not entirely sure. But wherever it is, we've arrived. Just beyond... these doors.
Voices fall silent.
I hate it when I join a party and everyone stops talking.
Welcome, Doctor. Ah, and one of the Tracers.
She has a name, don't you, Amy? But we haven't been introduced.
My name is unimportant.
Are you shy, or could your parents not agree?
The Tracer...
That's Amy.
Has brought the segments. I feel them. I need them.
Won't you introduce us to your friends? They're are so many, it may take a while.
My freedom fighters.
A ragtag battalion of many different races drawn here from across the universe. We met one of your recruits on the way in. Didn't make it, I'm afraid.
My master's army against the Key to Time. They will defy its power. Nothing shall ever be fore- ordained.
Literally fighting for freedom. I hadn't thought of it that way before.
Doors open.
She has the satchel, and the segments.
Ah, this is Zara and Professor Lydall. I imagine a platoon of angry Teuthoidians are hot on their heels. Perhaps some of this large crowd could help close...
Doors closed.
Those heavy doors. Goodness Professor, you're evidently a lot stronger than you look.
No! No, not now.
LYDALL-WHITE GUARDIAN: Oh, be quiet.
Bell.
Amy, are you all right?
Yes. What about all the others? How did he do...? Oh. I see.
Yes. Professor Lydall's really the White Guardian.
I didn't know myself until a moment ago. Exposure to the segments revitalised me. Brought me to my senses.
I've waited so long for this. You abandoned him in 9th century Africa, Doctor, but I rescued him and nursed him through the years, hunting for the Chaos Pool, hunting for the segments.
You can give them to me now, Amy, and I will bring or...
No.
Why?
You heard what she said about her freedom fighters. If the White Guardian has the Key, there will be no disorder in the universe.
That's good, isn't it?
It means no free will. He isn't a Guardian of virtue, he's a Guardian of control and domination.
I shall enforce the physical and temporal law...
The letter of the Law, not the spirit of it. You know very well that they're more like guidelines or theories.
Do you want chaos, Doctor? No boundaries, no order? To work from first principles for the slightest decision. At every turn would you calculate, shall I go left, or right...?
That's ridiculous.
Shall I eat, shall I blink, shall I breathe?
Autonomous processes that have nothing to do with free will. What about shall I care? Shall I help? Shall I show mercy?
You can't just make it up as you go along.
But that's precisely what we do. Complete certainty about everything - well, that's the tyranny of predestination.
I bring structure and order.
You bring helplessness and despair. You're a dictator.
But benevolent.
You can't be a benevolent dictator. Force is force.
Very good, Amy.
Ah, you've put thoughts into her mind, Doctor. So much for free will. Are you a dictator?
He's a teacher. I make my own choice about what to say.
Everything shall be counted, measured, described. There shall be nothing but logical reasoning and quantitative calculation.
No, no, no, no. Not everything can be defined. How do you measure the feeling of a sunset, the beauty of a butterfly's wing?
Dangerous things, butterflies. I can show you the mathematical calculations for a solitary beat of one wing that initiates a devastating tornado.

Butterflies dangerous? You would prefer to asphyxiate them and stick them in a display case. But a life well lived isn't pinned down by mathematics. Life is full of constants that aren’t, and variables that don't.
Give me the segments, Tracer.
Why don't you just take them? Because you can't, can you? Without the sixth segment, you don't have the power over me, or the Doctor.
But my help is given freely.
Zara, no, think what you would be doing...
The Tardis materialises, door opens.
Astra piloted the Tardis.
Impossible. Astra's still frozen over there. Romana!
Hello, Doctor. In deep trouble and bad company as usual?
I'm astonished to see you.
Well, you did send a telepathic message to Gallifrey.
Ah yes, the answer-phone.
I tracked down the Tardis in hyperspace, and it took me to some of your more recent destinations. Mars isn't quite how I remember it.
Ah well, long story.
But on 9th century Earth I was led to believe I would find you here.
Led to believe by whom?
Tardis door closes.
By me, Doctor.
I'm sorry, Doctor. I didn't realise who he was until it was too late.
The Black Guardian.
I was a wreck of my former self when Romana found me in Africa, Doctor, but my powers have returned. Behold!
Cheering.
Oh, you tiresome fellow.
You aren't the only one who can do party tricks, you know.
Master. Bow down before him.
Master.
Oh, do get up.
I don't understand. How could the Black Guardian rejuvenate again?
Prolonged contact with the sixth segment, I'm afraid.
Impossible. Astra has been here all the time.
Astra isn't the sixth segment, Doctor. I am.

parts.searchable_dialogue:
VOICE: [OC]: The final members of my army are arriving. Astra.
LYDALL: (echoes) Astra?
VOICE: [OC]: And Pargrave.
LYDALL: (echoes) Pargrave.
LYDALL: (echoes) Pargrave, don't get...
LYDALL: Too far ahead of us.
ASTRA: Captain Pargrave! I can see the light from his torch. He's crossed the stream, not far ahead. How are you doing, Lydall?
LYDALL: I'm still soaked from the storm, and the water's making these rocks slippery. I - I'm taking it carefully because of my hip. Ah! Oh no! Oh, my stick. Oh!
ASTRA: It's dropped right through the crack.
LYDALL: Can you see it?
ASTRA: Shine your torch down here too. No. The stream must have carried it away.
LYDALL: Oh, I'll have to manage without it.
ASTRA: That satchel looks like a burden. I could carry that for you.
LYDALL: I wouldn't dream of asking you to be my porter, Madam President.
ASTRA: Well, do you want to rest for a while?
LYDALL: Oh no, I'll be fine, thank you. Surprisingly I'd rather not stop. I feel compelled to persevere.
ASTRA: Yes, strange. Me too. Do you think it's getting colder?
LYDALL: Warmer, if anything.
ASTRA: Come on. Pargrave? Wait for us.
ASTRA: Oh my.
LYDALL: What? That's astonishing. Where's the light coming from?
PARGRAVE: Impressive, isn't it? Looks like a huge mausoleum.
LYDALL: Are they tombs? There are scores of them.
ASTRA: Maybe hundreds. See? They reach all the way up the walls. I can hardly count the ones at the top. The carvings on the monuments. These are the creatures that attacked the Eschaton.
LYDALL: Teuthoidians?
ASTRA: Is that what the Doctor called them?
PARGRAVE: Never mind the Doctor. We must keep moving.
ASTRA: How do you know which way to go, Captain? Do you feel what I feel - like you're being drawn onwards?
PARGRAVE: It's through here.
ASTRA: It? What is?
PARGRAVE: Our path.
ASTRA: Our path? Come on, Professor, let's follow our path. Don't forget your satchel.
AMY: The satchel is disintegrating. The segments are decaying and destroying everything around them. Doctor? I'm going to die in here.
LYDALL: [OC]: I wouldn't dream of asking you to be my porter, Madam President.
AMV: Is that you? Can you hear me? Can you hear me?
LYDALL: [OC]: I'm beginning to think you might...
LYDALL: Be right about this satchel.
ASTRA: Please let me carry the satchel for you, Lydall. It must be getting heavy.
LYDALL: Not heavy, no. It feels warmer though. It's odd.
AMY: [OC]: Can you hear me? Can you hear me?
LYDALL: What's that? Is someone there?
ASTRA: It's this mausoleum, Professor. It gives me the creeps too.
LYDALL: I'm sure I heard a voice.
ASTRA: Perhaps ahead of us in the cave network? Pargrave? Is there someone with you? What's that?
PARGRAVE: (distant) We must press on.
ASTRA: I shan't be sorry to leave this place.
ASTRA: Oh, I heard that.
LYDALL: It's an animal. It could just be sheltering from the storm.
ASTRA: Or tracking us through it. Come on.
AMY: Where's that dog thing gone? Oh, we've lost it.
DOCTOR: Him. We've lost him. I don't think he needs a torch.
DOCTOR: Or perhaps not. Come on. There's no other way. He must have gone through that archway. We can still catch up and escape this rain. Better to be under cover.
DOCTOR: AMY-ZARA: All right for you in that thing.
DOCTOR: Oh! Hope it regains its shape. I'm rather fond of this hat.
DOCTOR: AMY-ZARA: That dog thing got away. It wasn't ... He wasn't in any crash.
ZARA: Unlike us.
DOCTOR: An air hostess once told me that landings are just controlled crashes. Our canine friend probably relied on his auto-pilot too.
ZARA: It's a matter of trust. Do you think Pargrave trusted his auto-pilot, Doctor? He didn't trust me. And now he...
DOCTOR: As a matter of fact, I don't entirely trust you either. Where's the real Amy?
ZARA: What do you mean?
DOCTOR: Oh, come along. You've been a very poor impostor, Zara. Just look at you. In fact, I should have in my pocket... Yeah. Here it is.
ZARA: What's that? A knife?
DOCTOR: No, it's just a mirror. Look at yourself. Go on.
ZARA: I've changed.
DOCTOR: I know that feeling. I noticed your appearance was altering in the life raft, but I've known you weren't Amy for much longer than that.
ZARA: And said nothing?
DOCTOR: I've let you lead me on in the hope I'd find out what really happened to Amy. Your mutual existence is bound together as Tracers. Now that you're both becoming human, well, I'm beginning to worry more about the real Amy.
ZARA: I thought I had you fooled.
DOCTOR: You're too obvious, Zara. For example, maybe Pargrave was killed on landing...
ZARA: Don't say that!
DOCTOR: But Amy would be worried for his sake. You're only worried for yourself, because Pargrave abandoned you on the Eschaton.
ZARA: Oh, that's not fair!
DOCTOR: Where is she, Zara?
ZARA: You said we'd find the sixth...
DOCTOR: Zara...
ZARA: You said that dog-headed monstrosity could sniff it out for us.
DOCTOR: Where is Amy?
ZARA: Oh, she's in the satchel!
DOCTOR: What? That could kill her.
LYDALL: Pargrave is... Pargrave is very determined.
ASTRA: He says the Chaos Pool is close.
LYDALL: I think exhaustion and collapse are closer.
ASTRA: He seems to know the route, even though we've never been here before.
LYDALL: Like déja vu. Ow!
ASTRA: Oh, your hip?
LYDALL: The satchel. It gave me an electric shock. Ow!
ASTRA: Your hand. Pargrave, wait! The Professor is injured.
PARGRAVE: (distant) What's the problem?
ASTRA: Just leave it behind, Lydall.
AMY: [OC]: Who is that? Who's out there?
LYDALL: I'm not sure.
ASTRA: What use is a battered old satchel anyway? Oh, those are awful blisters, Lydall, and we abandoned the medikit in the wreck of the life raft.
PARGRAVE: What's the delay?
ASTRA: Just wait. How could the satchel burn you? What's in that thing?
LYDALL: I don't know. I can't open it. The buckle has bent. Look at the strap, it's disintegrated. And the
LYDALL: leather is splitting.
VOICE: [OC]: No. Do not leave the satchel. Bring it to me.
PARGRAVE: No. Do not leave the satchel.
ASTRA: Bring it to...
LYDALL: Oh, make your mind up. Oh. Forgive my impertinence, Madam President.
ASTRA: Bring the satchel. Pargrave will lead the way.
DOCTOR: What were you thinking?
ZARA: I trapped Amy in the satchel, all right? Used the transforming power of the segments to disguise myself as her. Well done, you're so smart. Happy now?
DOCTOR: Happy? I'm appalled. The pan-dimensional forces in that satchel could... Why, Zara?
ZARA: Well, you trust her, don't you, Doctor? I was thinking you'd never help me find the sixth segment, but you'd lead Amy right to it. Thought I'd got it too, when you told me about Astra. Huh. Didn't see that, did you? Not so smart after all.
DOCTOR: No. Well, I...
ZARA: And now look at me. No use as a Tracer because I'm turning human. Can't locate the segments anyway, because they're hidden in the bag.
DOCTOR: Well, we'll just have to hope that Lydall brought the bag with him, won't we? Assuming of course that their life raft wasn't crushed beneath the wreck of the Eschaton.
DOCTOR: Oh. Ev...
ZARA: He can't be.
DOCTOR: Here.
ZARA: Is this a trick?
DOCTOR: Er, no, no, it's called a hug.
ZARA: But my eyes are making your shoulder wet.
DOCTOR: It's already soaked from the storm.
ZARA: What's happening to me?
DOCTOR: They're tears, Zara. Have you never cried before?
ZARA: Pargrave makes me... makes me...
DOCTOR: Makes you feel this way.
ZARA: Yes. Thank you. I, I'll be fine now.
DOCTOR: Tell me about Pargrave.
ZARA: I found him on Atrios. I was going to use him just like I was using you, Doctor. Like I used Zinc.
DOCTOR: You left Zinc to die on Mars.
ZARA: Did I?
DOCTOR: Yes. No tears for him, Zara? What's so special about Pargrave?
ZARA: Pargrave is the 6th son of his family's 6th generation. I knew he would lead me back to the Chaos Pool. It's in his very essence, like the pilots of all those space craft we saw back there in the scrap-yard.
DOCTOR: They were drawn here too.
ZARA: From across the universe.
DOCTOR: Remarkable.
ZARA: Pargrave was in pieces when I met him. I was with him only a few months. Such a terrible time for him. His partner Francine and their children, they aged and died so swiftly. I made sure I stayed close to him. I just didn't expect... how close I'd got.
DOCTOR: You fell in love, for the first time in your short life. And Pargrave doesn't know?
ZARA: The Chaos Pool is all he cares about. That's why he abandoned us on the Eschaton, Doctor. Abandoned me. Didn't need me any more.
DOCTOR: Shh, shh! I don't think we have to worry about finding our canine friend. Quiet, Zara! He'll hear you.
AMY: [OC]: Help me, Zara! Things are falling apart. Help me!
ZARA: The satchel is decaying, Doctor, just like the segments.
DOCTOR: Where is it? What's happened to Amy?
ZARA: We must recover the satchel. We must recover the Key to Time.
DOCTOR: And Amy.
ZARA: I suppose.
DOCTOR: Quickly Zara, before that creature gets our scent. Too late.
LYDALL: Those doors are huge. Are you sure we could open them?
ASTRA: That one's slightly ajar. You can hear what's beyond them.
LYDALL: Let's take a look. What a crowd. Maybe a couple of hundred. That figure by the Pool. I imagine she's in charge. It that a mask? No, no, it's her face.
PARGRAVE: They're waiting.
LYDALL: Oh - and look at the waterfall. It drops straight into a big pool.
ASTRA: What's so important about that?
LYDALL: You can see a reflection on the surface, but there's no splashing when the waterfall hits it. It must be the Chaos Pool.
ASTRA: All a bit cloak and dagger don't you think?
LYDALL: I see what you mean about the cloak. It does nothing for her, does it?
ASTRA: No, I meant us. Skulking in this ante-chamber like this.
LYDALL: No, wait. We don't know what they are.
VOICE: Join us, President Astra.
FREEDOM FIGHTERS: Astra!
LYDALL: What?
ASTRA: Pargrave told you. They're waiting, for us.
VOICE: Astra.
FREEDOM FIGHTERS: Astra.
VOICE: Come in.
FREEDOM FIGHTERS: Come in.
LYDALL: They know who we are.
ASTRA: + VOICE: Of course they do.
VOICE: Step out into the dark.
ASTRA: Come on, Pargrave.
LYDALL: No. Don't go in.
ASTRA: They're expecting us.
ZARA: What's it doing?
DOCTOR: Ah-ah.
ZARA: Yeah right, now is the time for etiquette. What is he doing?
DOCTOR: Waving.
ZARA: What big teeth he has.
DOCTOR: All the better for smiling at us, I hope. Hello, I'm the Doctor, and this is Zara. He's not threatening us, he's beckoning us.
ZARA: What was all that howling before, then?
DOCTOR: Calling out. He wanted company. Come on. He's going without us. This is novel, being taken for a walk by the dog.
VOICE: The freedom fighters welcome you both.
FREEDOM FIGHTERS: Welcome.
PARGRAVE: The Chaos Pool. I thought I'd never see it.
VOICE: Captain Pargrave. 6th son of your 6th generation. President Astra, 6th daughter of a 6th Royal House. But there is a third. He has the segments.
ASTRA: Come out, Professor.
LYDALL: What is this place?
VOICE: The Chaos Pool. Is this not what you have sought for so long?
LYDALL: On the Eschaton the Doctor mentioned segments too. Are they in this satchel? It burns.
VOICE: Who is this?
ASTRA: This is Professor Lydall.
VOICE: No. Stay where you are!
LYDALL: Why are you afraid of me?
VOICE: Silence! He doesn't fully understand. Pargrave?
PARGRAVE: Mistress.
VOICE: Bring me that satchel.
LYDALL: You can't have it. Ah! Oh, it burns. Madam President, we must leave this dreadful place. The Chaos Pool is nothing like I imagined. This is wrong.
ASTRA: Give us the segments, Lydall.
LYDALL: Us? Oh Astra, not you as well.
VOICE: Surrender it to me. There are a thousand freedom fighters here. You have nowhere to run.
LYDALL: Tell them to take it from me. No. Look at them cowering. Are they afraid of me, or whatever it is in this satchel? You shan't have it!
PARGRAVE: Should I bring him back, Mistress?
VOICE: No. He will not pass through the Teuthoidian horde. And besides, my true master will arrive here soon.
ZARA: We know nothing about this dog thing.
DOCTOR: We know his bark is worse than his bite.
ZARA: You're very trusting, Doctor.
DOCTOR: You make that sound like a bad thing. Mind your step. This stream has made these stones somewhat treacherous. Our friend seems very sure-footed.
ZARA: Outside in the storm, Doctor, you wanted to help him even then. I can't decide whether that was brave or foolhardy.
DOCTOR: The line between them can be somewhat indistinct.
ZARA: How did you know it would be safe?
DOCTOR: I didn't. Nor that I would just abandon someone who might need my help.
ZARA: And now?
DOCTOR: Well, he's wagging his tail. It's supposed to be a good sign, isn't it? He's as harmless as a lamb.
ZARA: Then why do I feel like the sheep? Is he helping us or herding us. Oh!
DOCTOR: Are you all right, Zara? Here. Let me help you up.
ZARA: Look what I’ve found.
DOCTOR: Professor Lydall's walking-stick. Must have been washed downstream.
ZARA: I hope he's all right. Come on, we need to find him.
DOCTOR: That's more like it, Zara, don't abandon someone who might need our help.
ZARA: He has the segments in my satchel.
DOCTOR: Sounds like our friend has found something.
ZARA: Oh, wow. Look at this. It's a graveyard. A huge graveyard.
DOCTOR: A mausoleum.
ZARA: Hundreds of tombs. Look how high up they go.
DOCTOR: That's where the light's coming from. Natural illumination. Look at the carvings. Recognise this fellow?
ZARA: Yeah. I'm an expert on giant stone slugs. What do you think?
DOCTOR: Well, the dedication might give you a clue. See? Commander Hectocot.
ZARA: Hmm, he's quieter than I remember.
DOCTOR: Yes, finally at peace. This mausoleum is the last resting place of the Teuthoidians. How is that possible?
ZARA: What, 'cos they were alive and well attacking the Eschaton less than an hour ago?
DOCTOR: No, because this is the planet of Chaos, Zara. It has been held in stasis only minutes away from the end of the universe.
ZARA: You said that the Teuthoidians were from the other end of Time.
DOCTOR: Precisely.
ZARA: Is it safe?
DOCTOR: Some of the stones are coming loose. Try to stay away from the walls.
ZARA: That's not loose stones. The statues are splitting apart.
DOCTOR: It's Commander Hectocot. Silent no longer.
ZARA: I knew it was too good to be true.
HECTOCOT: Vermin. The pestilential infestation.
DOCTOR: Look out!
ZARA: Stay back, Doctor. You can't save the dog thing.
DOCTOR: That dog thing was helping us. We can't just abandon him. Let go of me, Zara.
ZARA: It's too late for him. The other monuments are splitting open. There are too many of them!
DOCTOR: That poor creature.
ZARA: You couldn't save him.
DOCTOR: I could have tried.
ZARA: We have to go. Come on, down this tunnel.
HECTOCOT: Teuthoidian cohort, to me.
MADDENUJOT: Lieutenant Maddenjot reporting for duty, sir.
HECTOCOT: Yes, all right, Maddenjot, gather...
HECTOCOT: (distant) The whole corps. Get them ready for pursuit.
ZARA: How can they be here?
DOCTOR: The planet of Chaos exists on a fold in Time that puts the beginning and the end of the universe side by side. The mausoleum must be a weak point. I couldn't save that poor creature.
ZARA: Would you really have sacrificed yourself to save it? You amaze me, Doctor.
DOCTOR: Your sister Amy said something very similar. Perhaps you're more alike than you care to admit.
ZARA: Something's ahead of us. We're trapped.
DOCTOR: No, wait! Professor Lydall.
ZARA: He has the satchel.
LYDALL: I understand now, Zara. Here, take it.
DOCTOR: Be careful, Zara. Look how it’s scorching his hands.
LYDALL: Oh, it burns!
ZARA: Give me the satchel. And my bracelet too.
LYDALL: Oh, it burns so brightly!
DOCTOR: Zara, no.
ZARA: At last.
DOCTOR: Amy.
AMY: Doctor. Doctor.
DOCTOR: Zara opened the satchel and let you out again.
ZARA: The segments. Where are the segments?
AMY: The satchel was disintegrating. The decaying segments were destroying it.
DOCTOR: It's all right, Amy. Look there. All that's left of the satchel.
ZARA: The segments must be here somewhere. Where are they?
AMY: Oh Doctor, I thought I was going to die in there.
DOCTOR: Let's try to avoid dying anywhere. The Teuthoidians are right behind us.
AMY: What, those awful slug creatures? Where are we, Doctor?
DOCTOR: I'll explain as we go. Lydall, what's down there? Lydall! You came from that direction. What's down there?
ZARA: Where are the segments?
HECTOCOT: (distant) The vermin are in this tunnel.
ZARA: The torch. Pass me the torch.
DOCTOR: Come on, Amy. Zara, Professor Lydall, we can't wait any longer.
ZARA: I have waited so long for you, haven't I?
PARGRAVE: Yes you have. And I have awoken. Now, where are the segments?
ZARA: I can't sense them. The Doctor said I might be more human than Tracer.
PARGRAVE: Your powers have not abated.
ZARA: But before. I couldn't detect the segments when they were in the s... The other satchel.
DOCTOR: They're in your satchel?
AMY: The segments are decaying badly. I had to stop them destroying Zara's satchel and me with it. At first I struggled to find them in there until I realised I just had to let them find me.
DOCTOR: You are brilliant.
AMY: Where are we going?
DOCTOR: I'm not entirely sure. But wherever it is, we've arrived. Just beyond... these doors.
DOCTOR: I hate it when I join a party and everyone stops talking.
VOICE: Welcome, Doctor. Ah, and one of the Tracers.
DOCTOR: She has a name, don't you, Amy? But we haven't been introduced.
VOICE: My name is unimportant.
DOCTOR: Are you shy, or could your parents not agree?
VOICE: The Tracer...
DOCTOR: That's Amy.
VOICE: Has brought the segments. I feel them. I need them.
DOCTOR: Won't you introduce us to your friends? They're are so many, it may take a while.
VOICE: My freedom fighters.
DOCTOR: A ragtag battalion of many different races drawn here from across the universe. We met one of your recruits on the way in. Didn't make it, I'm afraid.
VOICE: My master's army against the Key to Time. They will defy its power. Nothing shall ever be fore- ordained.
DOCTOR: Literally fighting for freedom. I hadn't thought of it that way before.
ZARA: She has the satchel, and the segments.
DOCTOR: Ah, this is Zara and Professor Lydall. I imagine a platoon of angry Teuthoidians are hot on their heels. Perhaps some of this large crowd could help close...
DOCTOR: Those heavy doors. Goodness Professor, you're evidently a lot stronger than you look.
VOICE: No! No, not now.
VOICE: LYDALL-WHITE GUARDIAN: Oh, be quiet.
DOCTOR: Amy, are you all right?
AMY: Yes. What about all the others? How did he do...? Oh. I see.
DOCTOR: Yes. Professor Lydall's really the White Guardian.
WHITE GUARDIAN: I didn't know myself until a moment ago. Exposure to the segments revitalised me. Brought me to my senses.
ZARA: I've waited so long for this. You abandoned him in 9th century Africa, Doctor, but I rescued him and nursed him through the years, hunting for the Chaos Pool, hunting for the segments.
WHITE GUARDIAN: You can give them to me now, Amy, and I will bring or...
DOCTOR: No.
AMY: Why?
DOCTOR: You heard what she said about her freedom fighters. If the White Guardian has the Key, there will be no disorder in the universe.
AMY: That's good, isn't it?
DOCTOR: It means no free will. He isn't a Guardian of virtue, he's a Guardian of control and domination.
WHITE GUARDIAN: I shall enforce the physical and temporal law...
DOCTOR: The letter of the Law, not the spirit of it. You know very well that they're more like guidelines or theories.
WHITE GUARDIAN: Do you want chaos, Doctor? No boundaries, no order? To work from first principles for the slightest decision. At every turn would you calculate, shall I go left, or right...?
DOCTOR: That's ridiculous.
WHITE GUARDIAN: Shall I eat, shall I blink, shall I breathe?
DOCTOR: Autonomous processes that have nothing to do with free will. What about shall I care? Shall I help? Shall I show mercy?
WHITE GUARDIAN: You can't just make it up as you go along.
DOCTOR: But that's precisely what we do. Complete certainty about everything - well, that's the tyranny of predestination.
WHITE GUARDIAN: I bring structure and order.
DOCTOR: You bring helplessness and despair. You're a dictator.
WHITE GUARDIAN: But benevolent.
AMY: You can't be a benevolent dictator. Force is force.
DOCTOR: Very good, Amy.
WHITE GUARDIAN: Ah, you've put thoughts into her mind, Doctor. So much for free will. Are you a dictator?
AMY: He's a teacher. I make my own choice about what to say.
WHITE GUARDIAN: Everything shall be counted, measured, described. There shall be nothing but logical reasoning and quantitative calculation.
DOCTOR: No, no, no, no. Not everything can be defined. How do you measure the feeling of a sunset, the beauty of a butterfly's wing?
WHITE GUARDIAN: Dangerous things, butterflies. I can show you the mathematical calculations for a solitary beat of one wing that initiates a devastating tornado.
DOCTOR: Butterflies dangerous? You would prefer to asphyxiate them and stick them in a display case. But a life well lived isn't pinned down by mathematics. Life is full of constants that aren’t, and variables that don't.
WHITE GUARDIAN: Give me the segments, Tracer.
AMY: Why don't you just take them? Because you can't, can you? Without the sixth segment, you don't have the power over me, or the Doctor.
ZARA: But my help is given freely.
DOCTOR: Zara, no, think what you would be doing...
AMV: Astra piloted the Tardis.
DOCTOR: Impossible. Astra's still frozen over there. Romana!
ROMANA: Hello, Doctor. In deep trouble and bad company as usual?
DOCTOR: I'm astonished to see you.
ROMANA: Well, you did send a telepathic message to Gallifrey.
DOCTOR: Ah yes, the answer-phone.
ROMANA: I tracked down the Tardis in hyperspace, and it took me to some of your more recent destinations. Mars isn't quite how I remember it.
DOCTOR: Ah well, long story.
ROMANA: But on 9th century Earth I was led to believe I would find you here.
DOCTOR: Led to believe by whom?
BLACK GUARDIAN: By me, Doctor.
ROMANA: I'm sorry, Doctor. I didn't realise who he was until it was too late.
DOCTOR: The Black Guardian.
BLACK GUARDIAN: I was a wreck of my former self when Romana found me in Africa, Doctor, but my powers have returned. Behold!
WHITE GUARDIAN: Oh, you tiresome fellow.
BLACK GUARDIAN: You aren't the only one who can do party tricks, you know.
VOICE: Master. Bow down before him.
FREEDOM FIGHTERS: Master.
BLACK GUARDIAN: Oh, do get up.
DOCTOR: I don't understand. How could the Black Guardian rejuvenate again?
ROMANA: Prolonged contact with the sixth segment, I'm afraid.
DOCTOR: Impossible. Astra has been here all the time.
ROMANA: Astra isn't the sixth segment, Doctor. I am.

elements.text: [Part Four]
That can't be.
After Astra was returned to Atrios, the segment was hidden within me. I should have worked it out sooner. My first incarnation didn't have to change. Seemed like a whim at the time.
Regeneration as a fashion statement.
It's not so funny now, I suppose. What's happened to Astra?
She's here, in thrall to the Black Guardian's agent, I'm afraid. Why are you here, Romana?
I persuaded her that I could locate you, Doctor. Her search drew strength from me while I drew strength from her.
So this is Romana.
Keep back, Zara. You will not convert her into the sixth segment.
My servants will prevent it. The segments must be allowed to decay.
Ah. That explains a lot.
The Key to Time must not be reassembled. There shall be no control.
Very good.
Ah, my servants have arrived. About time too.
Servants? These freedom fighters are people. Those Teuthoidian troops out there, they're people too.
Quite ugly people.
Not helping.
I will bring order.
You mean stasis. I will bring freedom.
You mean chaos. Tracer, release the segments to me.
You.
Yes, my lord.
Seize the Tracer.
Don't listen to the Guardians. Make your own choices. What is your name?
My name is un...

Unimportant. You said that before, but think what that means. These two, they're not just Tracers any more, they've learned something about themselves in the brief time they've been alive. They have names. This one lived on Atrios, made friends, started a career, fell in love. Her name's Zara. What's your name?
My name is... unimportant.
You've lived vicariously through these freedom fighters over generations but learned nothing from them. You're just the Black Guardian's vassal, and an empty vassal at that.
I have a name. I chose it. I'm Amy. This is my sister Zara.
It means Princess.
Now, my Princess. Your destiny is at hand.
[OC]: Open these doors, feeble-bodied weaklings, and then we shall all feast.
Why are the Guardians just waiting?
Everything is in balance.
Equilibrium.
Stability.
Impasse.
Until now. Complete your destiny, Tracer. Convert Romana into the final segment of the Key to Time.
Stay back, Zara. Amy, we must protect Romana.
Ignore him, Tracer, you're the counterpart to your sister. You should serve me.
I can't. That would bring anarchy. But if I help the White Guardian it'll be the last choice I ever make for myself.
Freedom fighters, advance.
Yes, my lord.
Open the doors.
Doors open.
Of course. I don't have to serve either of the Guardians. This is my choice.
Let go of me, Amy.
Amy, what are you doing?
Amy, stop!
GUARDIAN + WHITE GUARDIAN: Noooo!
Segment transformation.
Oh Amy, what have you done?
Doctor?
Romana. Romana, are you hurt?
My dignity, mostly.
Romana, I can't tell you how good it is to see you, and how sorry I am to have involved you.
Ah, it was inevitable.
I hope not.

My body's deteriorating. The Gallifreyan medics checked me over when I returned from E-Space. Their diagnosis was unambiguous. Regeneration is impossible. So when I got your message I didn't think I had a choice.
There's always a choice. Let me help you up. Marble floor must be cold.
Mmm, Gothic chic. I've never much liked draughty castles.
The castle. Oh Amy, you are brilliant.
And missing. When she grabbed my arm I thought was Amy trying to convert me into the sixth segment?
No, because you're still here.
And where is here exactly?
Former home of Lady Mesca Amuntik.
A Valdigian?
Well done.
The statues give it away. Classic arthropod ratio between the head thorax and abdomen. Distinctive wings.
Yes. This is the main hallway in the castle of Safeplace.
That sounds reassuring.
The castle is one of the segments in the Key to Time.
Ah. Not so reassuring after all. That explains the state it's in. Decaying, like all the others.
Amy took the segment from her pan-dimensional satchel and changed it back.
How's that possible?
She's a human Tracer, and so is her sister Zara. Or rather, they're both Tracers that have become human. Has its benefits. Although the Tracer we used didn't wander off on its own, did it?
Won't Zara just convert the castle back into a segment?
Not with the other four segments still inside Amy's satchel. Can't afford to trap them within another segment. We must find Amy.
Destroy the vermin.
How did these creatures find us, Pargrave?
I don't know, Madam President.
Hold back the intruders. Defend the Chaos Pool.
We're being overrun. What shall we do? Guardians, what can we do?
I can barely hear myself think.
I will stop mine if you will stop yours.
Oh, I suppose you're right.
Bell, silence.
Oh, what a relief. Thank you.
What have you done?
Are me and Astra the only ones you've not frozen?
You are each a special case.
Look. The castle wall. It's filled the whole of that far side of the cavern. How is that possible?
A property of the Key to Time, of course. It's here, and it's not here.
So I can convert it back into the segment.
Yes you can, if...
Here goes, then.
If you want to destroy the universe, so on the whole, I would not recommend it.
Oh. Because the other segments are inside it. Careless.
Design fault.
Well, don't look at me.
The other five segments must be retrieved first. The four that your sister has, and Romana. Well? Off you go.
What? Oh, yes. My bracelet.
Wibble.
Now, that was cheating.
There was nothing to forbid her from using the Time Ring.
You'd hardly break the rules, would you? I might, though. Time for my freedom fighters to invade the castle.
In that case my Teuthoidian army can assist Zara in her search.
When I first heard Astra's voice I thought you'd become President.
I wish. Those dullards in the High Council think Time begins and ends on Gallifrey. They can't see the storm that's coming.
Sounds like this castle is being stormed. Quick, up the stairs.
Crash.
What is this place, Maddenjot?
A derelict castle, Commander. Once home to a species of locusts, perhaps.
More vermin, Maddenjot. A plague of insects. Our Teuthoidian platoon will swarm through this castle and stamp them out.
Yes, Commander. Platoon! Start on the lower levels. Flush the vermin from their hiding-place.
That was interesting.
Oh!
Shh. Sorry, didn't mean to startle you.
These slug creatures seem very punctilious. We should be able to avoid them.
Yes, they're very by-the-book. Appropriate enough for servants of the White Guardian. Everything in order, everything inevitable.
Was it inevitable that I'd respond to your telepathic call, Doctor? That I'd unwittingly bring the Black Guardian to the Chaos Pool?
No. That would mean everything was predestined, and you don't believe that, do you?
Of course not. I think they've cleared the first floor. If we can slip past them, we'll be safe.
Unfortunately the Black Guardian's freedom fighters will take a more ad-hoc approach. Random incursions. I hope Amy's all right.
Oh, well done, Amy. Here again. Doctor? Romana? Wait a minute. I should be able to detect the sixth segment.
[OC]: What was that? Someone down there?
Oops.
Door opens.
Jarrow? Jarrow?
[OC]: What is it, Pargrave?
There's no one here, Jarrow. We should try the next level down. Hiding in a torture chamber. As if.
Door closes.
Oh. That was close.
Closer than you think.
Oh!
Another game while we wait?
We have waited millennia. We can continue while our agents operate. We are evenly matched.
But what of our partners? Are they co-equal? Or does your dependency on Astra weaken you?
Don't treat me like I'm not here.
We are your partners. You take your chances with us.
Bridge is a game of rules. A lead is taken, a suit must be followed, and contracts are made...
Or defeated. In a random deal nothing is predictable. And the contest is unequal when the dummy sits out the hand.
(laughs) I notice neither of you ever gets to be the dummy.
You over-reached last time. That was illogical. Your pre-emptive bid indicated a weak hand.
But I prevented you bidding and making a larger score.
A sacrifice?
A sacrifice is most effective during the final contract.
Is that freedom, or anarchy? Astra, you should bid.
Seven no trumps.
What?
A final sacrifice?
That remains to be seen. Now who's the dummy?
Ah. The castle's monitoring room. I remember it was tucked away in this turret. Ah no. This equipment's just a rusty pile of scrap, decaying like the rest of the castle.
I know how it feels.
Are you okay?
I'm not optimistic.
Here, sit down.
I've accepted it, Doctor. But what of Astra? She was returned to her old life.
At a terrible cost. Her rejuvenation was a curse on her and on the Atrian people. She survived for two hundred years by drawing energy from those around her.
Living forever, as her own people become extinct. That's horrible. Does she know?
No. She's laboured for centuries to diagnose her symptoms, and the dreadful thing is that she is the cause.
No. I am the cause, Doctor. And you know the only way to stop the Guardians.
Don't think that way.
Look at me, Doctor, properly. I'm a shell of my former self.
There must be an alternative.
You've already worked out that there isn't. You should complete the Key to Time. Amy must convert me into the sixth segment.
Nowhere to run.
Doctor!
I won't harm you. I just want that satchel.
You don't. Look, it's split and broken.
Good. My mistress wants it destroyed. The segments must never be reconstructed. They must be allowed to decay. Only then can we be free.
Wibble.
Zara. Where did you...?
I'll take that.
No! No, the lock is disintegrating - oh!
Jarrow, I have them. I will take the satchel.
It's tearing apart.
No!
Rip, clatter.
The segments.
Pick them up.
I can't hold them all. Here. Take two each.
We must have those segments. The only way out of this place is down those stairs. You won't get past us. I'll kill you first.
Kill me? After all I've meant to you? How I've stayed with you since Francine... since Francine and the children died.
They're dead. I have only this now.
What about me?
You're dead to me too, Zara. Take them.
All right. Look, we'll... we'll just hold the segments up for you. Amy, which segments do you have?
I have the compass and the capstone.
This is the shard of aurium, which means this is the first segment I found with Zinc. Hold tight to those chains, Amy.
Why?
Because this segment was the lake of Erratoon.
Flood.
Think this through rationally.
Don't patronise me, Doctor.
I'm sorry.
Well, stop being sorry and start looking for an exit.
I understand.
I really don't think you do. I thought I knew what Astra went through on Atrios. I was wrong.
Oh no.
Maddenjot to Commander Hectocot.
[OC]: Give me good news, Maddenjot.
We have them, Commander. West tower, main landing.
[OC]: Save a juicy one for me, Maddenjot. I'm on my way.
Take them.
Doctor?
We're cornered. The stairs only lead to the turret.
Rush of water.
What is this?
Quick, up the stairs. Hurry!
Men, fall back! Ah!
It's no good. The water's rising too quickly.
Romana, reach out for my hand. Romana! Romana!
Hold on, Jarrow. Hold on to the rail. Jarrow! The freedom fighters will prevail, Jarrow! The segments are still close by.
Romana. Romana! Romana!
Yes, all right! Do stop bellowing. Look at the damage. The castle was already crumbling to nothing, and now that flood has collapsed the stairs.
But you were drenched, and now you're not even damp.
Hello, Doctor.
Zara. Amy.
We have four segments of the Key to Time, Doctor. One used to be the lake of Erratoon. For a moment it was again until Zara changed it back.
This one, see? Every last drop.
Well done.
Romana, we must get you to the Tardis.
No, Doctor, you know where we must go.
To the Chaos Pool.
It's where we were born.
And where The Grace will be waiting.
What or who is The Grace?
The Grace created us, and the Key to Time. The Grace will restore balance from a point within the higher dimensions.
The Chaos Pool is a portal into those higher dimensions, in the gap between the Big Crunch and the Big Bang.
So the Chaos Pool is the crucible within which the Key to Time was forged, and where it can be disposed of without ending the universe.
The Key can't be the solution.
The Key is the problem. You know that its decaying segments must be reassembled, or annihilated. That includes me, Doctor.
I won't help you destroy yourself.
But I will.
Amy, you can't.
I thought I had a choice.
That's not what I meant.
Then whose choice is it, Doctor? Yours or Amy's? I know I've made mine.
Remain where you are, vermin.
Whoops. Time for a different decision. Across the landing, back into the banqueting hall.
And you are all on the menu.
Through here.
Er... Doctor?
Oh.
You've found us before we could find you. Seize the segments. If these people resist, kill them where they stand.
You haven't told me your name.
My name is unimportant, Astra.
Ah, you see? Names are a/ways important. They tell people who we are. I know, why not show the Black Guardian that you're free to choose one for yourself?
Is that possible? I suppose your bid altered the rules of the game.
They'll just carry on playing without us now. Look at them.
The Guardians can wait forever. You have no idea.
I have some idea. Average life expectancy for my people is now twenty nine years. I have lived among them for more than two centuries, and I have always felt alone.
I'm alone now, after all these millennia.
What about your freedom fighters?
They are constantly replenished. Every day new members arrive from across the universe. To live or die, while they wait for the inevitable reckoning.
Inevitable? That sounds like predestination. I thought you fought against that.
I no longer know what I'm fighting, why I exist, who I am. Why do you exist, Astra?
Well, I suppose I'm fighting for the future of my people.
You've outlived them. And you are responsible for their demise.
No!
You surrendered the sixth segment's essence to Romana. Now you Survive because you draw life directly from those around you on Atrios.
That can't be true.
And you have not saved a single one of them.
No more exits.
Use the lake of Erratoon again.
That could drown us all.
Or destroy the castle.
Use my Time Ring, Doctor. Take it. My hands are full.
Move in, everyone, and hold on tight.
Wibble.
What have you done with them?
They just vanished from the banqueting table.
Well, I'm still hungry.
Stand firm!
I believe that concludes this hand.
We are evenly matched.
But the game is about to change.
Wibble.
Well done, Zara.
Look out. The castle wall is collapsing.
Now, Amy, while the others are still inside the castle.
All right.
Transformation into segment.
There we go. Whoops! It’s tricky to manage three segments at once.
Easier to put them together, then. There. Just one piece missing.
Romana. Someone support her while I put my coat under her head. You'll be all right, Romana.
No I won't, I'm dying.
Five segments converted.
And the sixth at hand.
GUARDIAN + BLACK GUARDIAN: You have done well, Tracers.
And your life's work is over. Astra, bring me the Key to Time.
I don't think so.
You, bring me the Key.
Ask me nicely.
What?
Use my name.
You ... you have no name.
My name is Freedom. I am free of you at last.
Neither of us has to play the hand you've dealt us.
Very good, Astra. The Guardians are in perfect balance and they need someone to give them the edge. Look at you two! You can hardly speak. At a complete loss as to what to do.
Doctor, you shall...
Die for this!
I've heard that before. Romana.
Your friend Romana. I wish I could remember her from our first meeting, Doctor.
You'd have liked her.
I'm not dead just yet.
You cannot bear to see her die, as I saw my people die.
I'm so sorry, Astra.
Two hundred years of premature deaths. I couldn't save a single person. Now that must change.
Astra, be careful with her.
What's Astra doing to Romana?
It's called a hug.
Oh. I think we should hug them too.
Segment transformation.
Romana?
You were expecting someone else?
What happened to Asira?
She re-absorbed the essence of the sixth segment. See?
She holds the Key to Time.
And Astra is gone. She chose to sacrifice herself, for me.
The Key is completed.
But not active, not until Amy and Zara let go of it. Once the Tracers are removed, it will complete its transformation.
Bring it to me, Tracer.
I have a name, you know.
No, Tracer, bring it to me.
Oh, hello. Who's this?
I am the Grace.
The Grace.
It's The Grace!
At last.
Manifested in the Key. Very impressive. Up you get, Romana. Careful. Don't let go of the Key. Amy, Zara, you as well. So, you're The Grace, are you? You're who sent us on this mission.
May I have the Key?
No, I should have it.
Neither of you shall have it. Neither Guardian shall prevail. We banish you back to the howling void, and your eternal struggle.
No...
No, no!
Oh, bravo. Most impressive. Do I call you Grace or The Grace, or...?
Does it matter?
Names are important. They tell people who we are.
Silence. You are unimportant.
But I know who I am. I am Freedom.
We made you to serve, and you have done so through all the ages.
I never asked for eternity.
Then you shall have the only freedom we will offer.
Freedom screams.
There was no need to kill her like that!
She was a speck.
She was a person.
Tracers.
+ ZARA: Yes.
Take your hands from the Key to Time. Surrender it to the Grace. Your work is done, Tracers.
No. These young women aren't Tracers any more.
We made them as perfect devices.
Well, now they're human beings, with all the strengths and weaknesses and foibles and marvels that make them human.
(laughs) They are our creatures.
Let go of the key, Romana.
What?
Please. Thank you. Amy and Zara?
They do as we demand. They have no option.
I thought that was the whole point. Amy, do you trust me?
Of course.
Let go of the Key. Thank you. Now Zara, it's your choice. You can release the key and surrender it to the Grace, or you can give it to me.
We will crush you like an insect.
Not while Zara still holds on. You've manifested yourself in the Key. You can't leave it until everyone has let go.
Amy, what shall I do?
No, Zara. This is your choice.
Release us from the Key to Time. Obey us, Tracer.
My name is Zara. It means Princess. Here you are, Doctor.
Thank you, Zara.
Release the key.
Only one way to do that.
No!
Doctor!
Don't jump!
Running. Splash. Silence.
What's happened to the Chaos Pool?
The surface vanished after the Doctor jumped in. Be careful! It's a long way down.
It's just a dark chasm now, full of jagged rocks.
Oh Doctor, I wish you'd let me help.
(distant) Well, you could give me a hand out of here.
+ AMY + ZARA: Doctor!
How did you know that ledge was there?
I didn't. I just knew the Chaos Pool would disintegrate the Key.
A leap of faith?
I suppose so. The Grace are dispersed throughout eternity. Everyone trapped in the castle segment will be returned home.
Including Pargrave?
I hope so. You'll find out back on Atrios. Here's your Time Ring.
Doctor, how can you just let me go like this, after everything I did? I was bitter, and hurtful...
And brave and compassionate. People aren't perfect, Zara. That's what makes them people and not artificial personnel. You're not artificial. You're a real person.
You took a risk by giving us that choice.
If I compelled you, Amy, I'd be no better than the Grace.
You risked the whole universe on your faith that I was really a good person?
Yes.
I don't think I like that thought. Frankly it terrifies me.
What's that on your face, Zara?
They're tears. I learned that from the Doctor.
It happens a lot with the Doctor.
Will you come too, Amy?
I have other plans. Go on, Zara. Pargrave will be waiting.
Bye, everyone. Doctor, thank you.
Wibble.
You two look very conspiratorial. Sorry to interrupt, Romana, but it's time to get you home. Amy, you can help me find Peri.
I think my searching is over.
We located the Key to Time, yes, but...
Romana's invited me back to Gallifrey.
Oh.
We should open the Academy to non-Gallifreyans. This whole experience makes me think the Time Lords should be less parochial.
And I've accepted her offer.
To persuade the High Council, I need someone I can trust. And I trust Amy with my life. In fact, I did.
Is this what you want?
Yes, Doctor. It's like... destiny.
Nothing's predetermined. It's your choice.
And you still have a lot to learn.
Well, perhaps my true search is just beginning. And you, Doctor? What are you really looking for?
I... Er, well...
Doctor?
I'll tell you when I find it. Come on.

parts.searchable_dialogue:
DOCTOR: That can't be.
ROMANA: After Astra was returned to Atrios, the segment was hidden within me. I should have worked it out sooner. My first incarnation didn't have to change. Seemed like a whim at the time.
DOCTOR: Regeneration as a fashion statement.
ROMANA: It's not so funny now, I suppose. What's happened to Astra?
DOCTOR: She's here, in thrall to the Black Guardian's agent, I'm afraid. Why are you here, Romana?
BLACK GUARDIAN: I persuaded her that I could locate you, Doctor. Her search drew strength from me while I drew strength from her.
ZARA: So this is Romana.
DOCTOR: Keep back, Zara. You will not convert her into the sixth segment.
BLACK GUARDIAN: My servants will prevent it. The segments must be allowed to decay.
ROMANA: Ah. That explains a lot.
VOICE: The Key to Time must not be reassembled. There shall be no control.
BLACK GUARDIAN: Very good.
WHITE GUARDIAN: Ah, my servants have arrived. About time too.
DOCTOR: Servants? These freedom fighters are people. Those Teuthoidian troops out there, they're people too.
AMY: Quite ugly people.
DOCTOR: Not helping.
WHITE GUARDIAN: I will bring order.
BLACK GUARDIAN: You mean stasis. I will bring freedom.
WHITE GUARDIAN: You mean chaos. Tracer, release the segments to me.
BLACK GUARDIAN: You.
VOICE: Yes, my lord.
BLACK GUARDIAN: Seize the Tracer.
DOCTOR: Don't listen to the Guardians. Make your own choices. What is your name?
VOICE: My name is un...
DOCTOR: Unimportant. You said that before, but think what that means. These two, they're not just Tracers any more, they've learned something about themselves in the brief time they've been alive. They have names. This one lived on Atrios, made friends, started a career, fell in love. Her name's Zara. What's your name?
VOICE: My name is... unimportant.
DOCTOR: You've lived vicariously through these freedom fighters over generations but learned nothing from them. You're just the Black Guardian's vassal, and an empty vassal at that.
AMY: I have a name. I chose it. I'm Amy. This is my sister Zara.
ZARA: It means Princess.
WHITE GUARDIAN: Now, my Princess. Your destiny is at hand.
HECTOCOT: [OC]: Open these doors, feeble-bodied weaklings, and then we shall all feast.
ROMANA: Why are the Guardians just waiting?
WHITE GUARDIAN: Everything is in balance.
BLACK GUARDIAN: Equilibrium.
WHITE GUARDIAN: Stability.
BLACK GUARDIAN: Impasse.
WHITE GUARDIAN: Until now. Complete your destiny, Tracer. Convert Romana into the final segment of the Key to Time.
DOCTOR: Stay back, Zara. Amy, we must protect Romana.
BLACK GUARDIAN: Ignore him, Tracer, you're the counterpart to your sister. You should serve me.
AMY: I can't. That would bring anarchy. But if I help the White Guardian it'll be the last choice I ever make for myself.
BLACK GUARDIAN: Freedom fighters, advance.
VOICE: Yes, my lord.
WHITE GUARDIAN: Open the doors.
AMY: Of course. I don't have to serve either of the Guardians. This is my choice.
ROMANA: Let go of me, Amy.
DOCTOR: Amy, what are you doing?
ROMANA: Amy, stop!
BLACK: GUARDIAN + WHITE GUARDIAN: Noooo!
DOCTOR: Oh Amy, what have you done?
ROMANA: Doctor?
DOCTOR: Romana. Romana, are you hurt?
ROMANA: My dignity, mostly.
DOCTOR: Romana, I can't tell you how good it is to see you, and how sorry I am to have involved you.
ROMANA: Ah, it was inevitable.
DOCTOR: I hope not.
ROMANA: My body's deteriorating. The Gallifreyan medics checked me over when I returned from E-Space. Their diagnosis was unambiguous. Regeneration is impossible. So when I got your message I didn't think I had a choice.
DOCTOR: There's always a choice. Let me help you up. Marble floor must be cold.
ROMANA: Mmm, Gothic chic. I've never much liked draughty castles.
DOCTOR: The castle. Oh Amy, you are brilliant.
ROMANA: And missing. When she grabbed my arm I thought was Amy trying to convert me into the sixth segment?
DOCTOR: No, because you're still here.
ROMANA: And where is here exactly?
DOCTOR: Former home of Lady Mesca Amuntik.
ROMANA: A Valdigian?
DOCTOR: Well done.
ROMANA: The statues give it away. Classic arthropod ratio between the head thorax and abdomen. Distinctive wings.
DOCTOR: Yes. This is the main hallway in the castle of Safeplace.
ROMANA: That sounds reassuring.
DOCTOR: The castle is one of the segments in the Key to Time.
ROMANA: Ah. Not so reassuring after all. That explains the state it's in. Decaying, like all the others.
DOCTOR: Amy took the segment from her pan-dimensional satchel and changed it back.
ROMANA: How's that possible?
DOCTOR: She's a human Tracer, and so is her sister Zara. Or rather, they're both Tracers that have become human. Has its benefits. Although the Tracer we used didn't wander off on its own, did it?
ROMANA: Won't Zara just convert the castle back into a segment?
DOCTOR: Not with the other four segments still inside Amy's satchel. Can't afford to trap them within another segment. We must find Amy.
HECTOCOT: Destroy the vermin.
ASTRA: How did these creatures find us, Pargrave?
PARGRAVE: I don't know, Madam President.
VOICE: Hold back the intruders. Defend the Chaos Pool.
ZARA: We're being overrun. What shall we do? Guardians, what can we do?
BLACK GUARDIAN: I can barely hear myself think.
WHITE GUARDIAN: I will stop mine if you will stop yours.
BLACK GUARDIAN: Oh, I suppose you're right.
ZARA: Oh, what a relief. Thank you.
ASTRA: What have you done?
ZARA: Are me and Astra the only ones you've not frozen?
WHITE GUARDIAN: You are each a special case.
ZARA: Look. The castle wall. It's filled the whole of that far side of the cavern. How is that possible?
WHITE GUARDIAN: A property of the Key to Time, of course. It's here, and it's not here.
ZARA: So I can convert it back into the segment.
WHITE GUARDIAN: Yes you can, if...
ZARA: Here goes, then.
WHITE GUARDIAN: If you want to destroy the universe, so on the whole, I would not recommend it.
ZARA: Oh. Because the other segments are inside it. Careless.
WHITE GUARDIAN: Design fault.
BLACK GUARDIAN: Well, don't look at me.
WHITE GUARDIAN: The other five segments must be retrieved first. The four that your sister has, and Romana. Well? Off you go.
ZARA: What? Oh, yes. My bracelet.
BLACK GUARDIAN: Now, that was cheating.
WHITE GUARDIAN: There was nothing to forbid her from using the Time Ring.
BLACK GUARDIAN: You'd hardly break the rules, would you? I might, though. Time for my freedom fighters to invade the castle.
WHITE GUARDIAN: In that case my Teuthoidian army can assist Zara in her search.
DOCTOR: When I first heard Astra's voice I thought you'd become President.
ROMANA: I wish. Those dullards in the High Council think Time begins and ends on Gallifrey. They can't see the storm that's coming.
DOCTOR: Sounds like this castle is being stormed. Quick, up the stairs.
HECTOCOT: What is this place, Maddenjot?

HECTOCOT: More vermin, Maddenjot. A plague of insects. Our Teuthoidian platoon will swarm through this castle and stamp them out.
MADDENUJOT: Yes, Commander. Platoon! Start on the lower levels. Flush the vermin from their hiding-place.
DOCTOR: That was interesting.
ROMANA: Oh!
DOCTOR: Shh. Sorry, didn't mean to startle you.
ROMANA: These slug creatures seem very punctilious. We should be able to avoid them.
DOCTOR: Yes, they're very by-the-book. Appropriate enough for servants of the White Guardian. Everything in order, everything inevitable.
ROMANA: Was it inevitable that I'd respond to your telepathic call, Doctor? That I'd unwittingly bring the Black Guardian to the Chaos Pool?
DOCTOR: No. That would mean everything was predestined, and you don't believe that, do you?
ROMANA: Of course not. I think they've cleared the first floor. If we can slip past them, we'll be safe.
DOCTOR: Unfortunately the Black Guardian's freedom fighters will take a more ad-hoc approach. Random incursions. I hope Amy's all right.
AMY: Oh, well done, Amy. Here again. Doctor? Romana? Wait a minute. I should be able to detect the sixth segment.
PARGRAVE: [OC]: What was that? Someone down there?
AMY: Oops.
PARGRAVE: Jarrow? Jarrow?
JARROW: [OC]: What is it, Pargrave?
PARGRAVE: There's no one here, Jarrow. We should try the next level down. Hiding in a torture chamber. As if.
AMY: Oh. That was close.
PARGRAVE: Closer than you think.
AMY: Oh!
BLACK GUARDIAN: Another game while we wait?
WHITE GUARDIAN: We have waited millennia. We can continue while our agents operate. We are evenly matched.
BLACK GUARDIAN: But what of our partners? Are they co-equal? Or does your dependency on Astra weaken you?
ASTRA: Don't treat me like I'm not here.
VOICE: We are your partners. You take your chances with us.
WHITE GUARDIAN: Bridge is a game of rules. A lead is taken, a suit must be followed, and contracts are made...

WHITE GUARDIAN: You over-reached last time. That was illogical. Your pre-emptive bid indicated a weak hand.
BLACK GUARDIAN: But I prevented you bidding and making a larger score.
ASTRA: A sacrifice?
BLACK GUARDIAN: A sacrifice is most effective during the final contract.
WHITE GUARDIAN: Is that freedom, or anarchy? Astra, you should bid.

WHITE GUARDIAN: What?
BLACK GUARDIAN: A final sacrifice?

DOCTOR: Are you okay?

ROMANA: Living forever, as her own people become extinct. That's horrible. Does she know?
DOCTOR: No. She's laboured for centuries to diagnose her symptoms, and the dreadful thing is that she is the cause.
ROMANA: No. I am the cause, Doctor. And you know the only way to stop the Guardians.
DOCTOR: Don't think that way.
ROMANA: Look at me, Doctor, properly. I'm a shell of my former self.
DOCTOR: There must be an alternative.
ROMANA: You've already worked out that there isn't. You should complete the Key to Time. Amy must convert me into the sixth segment.

ZARA: What about me?

ZARA: This is the shard of aurium, which means this is the first segment I found with Zinc. Hold tight to those chains, Amy.

DOCTOR: Think this through rationally.
ROMANA: Don't patronise me, Doctor.
DOCTOR: I'm sorry.

MADDENUJOT: Take them.

DOCTOR: Romana. Romana! Romana!
ROMANA: Yes, all right! Do stop bellowing. Look at the damage. The castle was already crumbling to nothing, and now that flood has collapsed the stairs.

ZARA: Hello, Doctor.
DOCTOR: Zara. Amy.
AMY: We have four segments of the Key to Time, Doctor. One used to be the lake of Erratoon. For a moment it was again until Zara changed it back.
ZARA: This one, see? Every last drop.
ROMANA: Well done.
DOCTOR: Romana, we must get you to the Tardis.
ROMANA: No, Doctor, you know where we must go.
ZARA: To the Chaos Pool.
AMY: It's where we were born.

DOCTOR: I won't help you destroy yourself.
AMY: But I will.
DOCTOR: Amy, you can't.
AMY: I thought I had a choice.
DOCTOR: That's not what I meant.
ROMANA: Then whose choice is it, Doctor? Yours or Amy's? I know I've made mine.
HECTOCOT: Remain where you are, vermin.
DOCTOR: Whoops. Time for a different decision. Across the landing, back into the banqueting hall.
HECTOCOT: And you are all on the menu.
DOCTOR: Through here.
AMY: Er... Doctor?
DOCTOR: Oh.
PARGRAVE: You've found us before we could find you. Seize the segments. If these people resist, kill them where they stand.
ASTRA: You haven't told me your name.
VOICE: My name is unimportant, Astra.
ASTRA: Ah, you see? Names are a/ways important. They tell people who we are. I know, why not show the Black Guardian that you're free to choose one for yourself?
VOICE: Is that possible? I suppose your bid altered the rules of the game.
ASTRA: They'll just carry on playing without us now. Look at them.
VOICE: The Guardians can wait forever. You have no idea.

VOICE: I no longer know what I'm fighting, why I exist, who I am. Why do you exist, Astra?

VOICE: You've outlived them. And you are responsible for their demise.

VOICE: You surrendered the sixth segment's essence to Romana. Now you Survive because you draw life directly from those around you on Atrios.
